children.subject: Yes, it is by design. The instructor will tell you how to get into the actual sections during the first class.

CS70 Discussions?

I've been enrolled in the CS70 lecture for a while now but I just realized that I'm not signed up for a discussion. I've tried to change this under the options menu but it doesn't seem that any cs 70 discussions are posted/up. Is this normal?
Search the capacity of 186 in classes.berkeley.edu, and you will find the sad truth.

CS186 Enrollment question? As I know, the lecture capacity is 525 and the 15 discussion section offers 15 * 35 = 525 seats in total. However, the capacity of the course is upper bound by the fact that the 999 section has only 400 seats. Will this be resolved soon?
See the bolded line in the post.
How do we know which room to go to for discussion if we are signed up for a 999 discussion?

history.content:
New for select classes (upper div and a few lower div CS classes) in Fall 2017

We are trying something new to avoid the dreaded drop/re-enroll situation when you are wait listed and want to change sections. You know that scenario - one mistake and you end up further down the wait list than you were when you started.

To avoid this, we have created 999 sections for some classes. These sections are placeholders and do not actually have any meeting day/time. When you enroll in the class, you can only sign up for the lecture and this 999 section.

Separately, we have created the actual sections and you can see those in classes.berkeley.edu so you can plan your schedule but you cannot enroll in those classes through the enrollment system.

Instead, go to the first lecture and the instructor will give you directions about getting into the actual sections for the class. Yes, we know this requires patience on your part to know which actual session you will attend but it bypasses the dreaded bump to the bottom of the wait list by accident.
